00023 #ifndef _ODE_COMMON_H_

00033 
00034 /* configuration stuff */
00035 
00036 /* the efficient alignment. most platforms align data structures to some
00037  * number of bytes, but this is not always the most efficient alignment.
00038  * for example, many x86 compilers align to 4 bytes, but on a pentium it
00039  * is important to align doubles to 8 byte boundaries (for speed), and
00040  * the 4 floats in a SIMD register to 16 byte boundaries. many other
00041  * platforms have similar behavior. setting a larger alignment can waste
00042  * a (very) small amount of memory. NOTE: this number must be a power of
00043  * two. this is set to 16 by default.
00044  */
00045 #define EFFICIENT_ALIGNMENT 16
00046 
00047 
00048 /* constants */
00049 
00050 /* pi and 1/sqrt(2) are defined here if necessary because they don't get
00051  * defined in <math.h> on some platforms (like MS-Windows)
00052  */
00053 
00054 #ifndef M_PI
00055 #define M_PI REAL(3.1415926535897932384626433832795029)
00056 #endif
00057 #ifndef M_SQRT1_2
00058 #define M_SQRT1_2 REAL(0.7071067811865475244008443621048490)
00059 #endif
00060 
00061 
00062 /* debugging:
00063  *   IASSERT  is an internal assertion, i.e. a consistency check. if it fails
00064  *            we want to know where.
00065  *   UASSERT  is a user assertion, i.e. if it fails a nice error message
00066  *            should be printed for the user.
00067  *   AASSERT  is an arguments assertion, i.e. if it fails "bad argument(s)"
00068  *            is printed.
00069  *   DEBUGMSG just prints out a message
00070  */
00071 
00072 #ifndef dNODEBUG
00073 #ifdef __GNUC__
00074 #define dIASSERT(a) if (!(a)) dDebug (d_ERR_IASSERT, \
00075   "assertion \"" #a "\" failed in %s() [%s]",__FUNCTION__,__FILE__);
00076 #define dUASSERT(a,msg) if (!(a)) dDebug (d_ERR_UASSERT, \
00077   msg " in %s()", __FUNCTION__);
00078 #define dDEBUGMSG(msg) dMessage (d_ERR_UASSERT, \
00079   msg " in %s()", __FUNCTION__);
00080 #else
00081 #define dIASSERT(a) if (!(a)) dDebug (d_ERR_IASSERT, \
00082   "assertion \"" #a "\" failed in %s:%d",__FILE__,__LINE__);
00083 #define dUASSERT(a,msg) if (!(a)) dDebug (d_ERR_UASSERT, \
00084   msg " (%s:%d)", __FILE__,__LINE__);
00085 #define dDEBUGMSG(msg) dMessage (d_ERR_UASSERT, \
00086   msg " (%s:%d)", __FILE__,__LINE__);
00087 #endif
00088 #else
00089 #define dIASSERT(a) ;
00090 #define dUASSERT(a,msg) ;
00091 #define dDEBUGMSG(msg) ;
00092 #endif
00093 #define dAASSERT(a) dUASSERT(a,"Bad argument(s)")
00094 
00095 /* floating point data type, vector, matrix and quaternion types */
00096 
00097 #if defined(dSINGLE)
00098 typedef float dReal;
00099 #elif defined(dDOUBLE)
00100 typedef double dReal;
00101 #else
00102 #error You must #define dSINGLE or dDOUBLE
00103 #endif
00104 
00105 
00106 /* round an integer up to a multiple of 4, except that 0 and 1 are unmodified
00107  * (used to compute matrix leading dimensions)
00108  */
00109 #define dPAD(a) (((a) > 1) ? ((((a)-1)|3)+1) : (a))
00110 
00111 /* these types are mainly just used in headers */
00112 typedef dReal dVector3[4];
00113 typedef dReal dVector4[4];
00114 typedef dReal dMatrix3[4*3];
00115 typedef dReal dMatrix4[4*4];
00116 typedef dReal dMatrix6[8*6];
00117 typedef dReal dQuaternion[4];
00118 
00119 
00120 /* precision dependent scalar math functions */
00121 
00122 #if defined(dSINGLE)
00123 
00124 #define REAL(x) (x ## f)                    /* form a constant */
00125 #define dRecip(x) ((float)(1.0f/(x)))               /* reciprocal */
00126 #define dSqrt(x) ((float)sqrtf(float(x)))           /* square root */
00127 #define dRecipSqrt(x) ((float)(1.0f/sqrtf(float(x))))       /* reciprocal square root */
00128 #define dSin(x) ((float)sinf(float(x)))             /* sine */
00129 #define dCos(x) ((float)cosf(float(x)))             /* cosine */
00130 #define dFabs(x) ((float)fabsf(float(x)))           /* absolute value */
00131 #define dAtan2(y,x) ((float)atan2f(float(y),float(x)))      /* arc tangent with 2 args */
00132 #define dFMod(a,b) ((float)fmodf(float(a),float(b)))        /* modulo */
00133 #define dCopySign(a,b) ((float)copysignf(float(a),float(b)))
00134 
00135 #elif defined(dDOUBLE)
00136 
00137 #define REAL(x) (x)
00138 #define dRecip(x) (1.0/(x))
00139 #define dSqrt(x) sqrt(x)
00140 #define dRecipSqrt(x) (1.0/sqrt(x))
00141 #define dSin(x) sin(x)
00142 #define dCos(x) cos(x)
00143 #define dFabs(x) fabs(x)
00144 #define dAtan2(y,x) atan2((y),(x))
00145 #define dFMod(a,b) (fmod((a),(b)))
00146 #define dCopySign(a,b) (copysign((a),(b)))
00147 
00148 #else
00149 #error You must #define dSINGLE or dDOUBLE
00150 #endif
00151 
00152 
00153 /* utility */
00154 
00155 
00156 /* round something up to be a multiple of the EFFICIENT_ALIGNMENT */
00157 
00158 #define dEFFICIENT_SIZE(x) ((((x)-1)|(EFFICIENT_ALIGNMENT-1))+1)
00159 
00160 
00161 /* alloca aligned to the EFFICIENT_ALIGNMENT. note that this can waste
00162  * up to 15 bytes per allocation, depending on what alloca() returns.
00163  */
00164 
00165 #define dALLOCA16(n) \
00166   ((char*)dEFFICIENT_SIZE(((size_t)(alloca((n)+(EFFICIENT_ALIGNMENT-1))))))
00167

00169 /* internal object types (all prefixed with `dx') */
00170 
00171 struct dxWorld;     /* dynamics world */
00172 struct dxSpace;     /* collision space */
00173 struct dxBody;      /* rigid body (dynamics object) */
00174 struct dxGeom;      /* geometry (collision object) */
00175 struct dxJoint;
00176 struct dxJointNode;
00177 struct dxJointGroup;
00178 
00179 typedef struct dxWorld *dWorldID;
00180 typedef struct dxSpace *dSpaceID;
00181 typedef struct dxBody *dBodyID;
00182 typedef struct dxGeom *dGeomID;
00183 typedef struct dxJoint *dJointID;
00184 typedef struct dxJointGroup *dJointGroupID;

00214  * structures and member constants. we don't actually do this yet.

00221   dReal vel, fmax;
00222   dReal fudge_factor;
00223   dReal bounce, soft;
00224   dReal suspension_erp, suspension_cfm;
00225 } dLimot;
00226 
00227 enum {
00228   dLimotLoStop      = 0x0001,
00229   dLimotHiStop      = 0x0002,
00230   dLimotVel     = 0x0004,
00231   dLimotFMax        = 0x0008,

00238 
00239 /* standard joint parameter names. why are these here? - because we don't want
00240  * to include all the joint function definitions in joint.cpp. hmmmm.
00241  * MSVC complains if we call D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES_X with a blank second argument,
00242  * which is why we have the D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES macro as well. please copy and
00243  * paste between these two.
00244  */
00245 
00246 #define D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES(start) \
00247   /* parameters for limits and motors */ \
00248   dParamLoStop = start, \
00249   dParamHiStop, \
00250   dParamVel, \
00251   dParamFMax, \
00252   dParamFudgeFactor, \
00253   dParamBounce, \
00254   dParamCFM, \
00255   dParamStopERP, \
00256   dParamStopCFM, \
00257   /* parameters for suspension */ \
00258   dParamSuspensionERP, \
00259   dParamSuspensionCFM,
00260 
00261 #define D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES_X(start,x) \
00262   /* parameters for limits and motors */ \
00263   dParamLoStop ## x = start, \
00264   dParamHiStop ## x, \
00265   dParamVel ## x, \
00266   dParamFMax ## x, \
00267   dParamFudgeFactor ## x, \
00268   dParamBounce ## x, \
00269   dParamCFM ## x, \
00270   dParamStopERP ## x, \
00271   dParamStopCFM ## x, \
00272   /* parameters for suspension */ \
00273   dParamSuspensionERP ## x, \
00274   dParamSuspensionCFM ## x,
00275 
00276 enum {
00277   D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES(0)
00278   D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES_X(0x100,2)
00279   D_ALL_PARAM_NAMES_X(0x200,3)
00280 
00281   /* add a multiple of this constant to the basic parameter numbers to get
00282    * the parameters for the second, third etc axes.
00283    */
00284   dParamGroup=0x100
00285 };
00286

00288 /* angular motor mode numbers */
00289 
00290 enum{
00291   dAMotorUser = 0,
00292   dAMotorEuler = 1
00293 };

00295 
00296 /* joint force feedback information */
00297 
00298 typedef struct dJointFeedback {
00299   dVector3 f1;      /* force applied to body 1 */
00300   dVector3 t1;      /* torque applied to body 1 */
00301   dVector3 f2;      /* force applied to body 2 */
00302   dVector3 t2;      /* torque applied to body 2 */
00303 } dJointFeedback;
00304 
00305 
00306 /* private functions that must be implemented by the collision library:
00307  * (1) indicate that a geom has moved, (2) get the next geom in a body list.
00308  * these functions are called whenever the position of geoms connected to a
00309  * body have changed, e.g. with dBodySetPosition(), dBodySetRotation(), or
00310  * when the ODE step function updates the body state.
00311  */
00312 
00313 void dGeomMoved (dGeomID);
00314 dGeomID dGeomGetBodyNext (dGeomID);
00315
